comment: Thanks for the great feedback so far and so happy many of you will finally get to watch the doc! To everyone outside of the US who isn't able to watch the film - we'll keep you updated as the service rolls out across different parts of the world. At the moment it is only available in the United States including American Samoa, Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Link in bio for a 7-day free trial.  Happy New Year!

"Streaming access is available only when you are located in the U.S. and certain U.S. territories." - well that's a bugger!

@showmoke I'm not sure about what you say about the IP address. There are only so many to go around, so ISPs allocate them dynamically, unless you pay a premium for them not to do that. And if you use more than one provider, such as your home cable router and IP over your cell phone provider, would that not be an issue? What VPNs do is create a virtual "tunnel" that allocates you one of their "local" IP addresses, and I think that, because they are quite "well known" certain streaming services simply black list them.

@Julian Idle Some online companies seem to know that you are using a VPN, for example most UK bookmakers. If your IP address is different to the one that they have in their records which they tie up with your email address, then when you activate your VPN, then their software will automatically block you access to their website, That may of course be the same as the online streaming companies, but I'm not sure.
@showmoke usually, unless the streaming service is wise to the IP address of the VPN being a VPN!
Can you get around that if you use a VPN and set it to the USA?
